content.webTitle: Marriage equality, asylum seekers, renewables: McGowan launches Indi campaign

fields.headline: Marriage equality, asylum seekers, renewables: McGowan launches Indi campaign
fields.bodyText: Independent Cathy McGowan has used her election campaign launch to outline an unashamedly progressive platform, pledging to support legislated time limits for refugee detention, marriage equality, renewables, regional employment and fixed four-year terms. And she promised to “make no deals” to compromise her independence. “When I am re-elected, I will make no deals that compromise my independence or ability to put the interest of the people of Indi first,” McGowan said. “I will represent. I will lobby and advocate so that our taxes return to us to build the infrastructure and support services.” In front of 500 supporters, McGowan outlined her legislative record and policies but it was a call for both parties to support Australia’s United Nations commitments to asylum seekers that attracted the largest cheer from the Wodonga crowd. “In regional Australia we seek to be good neighbours to others in time of need,” McGowan said. “The same should apply to those seeking asylum to our country. I believe the Australian government has a duty of care to protect the safety and health of the people who come here seeking our protection. “I call on both parties to commit to protect people from harm and honour our commitments to the United Nations; to stop detaining children, and to legislate time limits for detention.” McGowan was seeking to kickstart her campaign to win a second term in office in the Victorian seat, after beating the former Liberal frontbencher Sophie Mirabella in 2013. Mirabella is running again in the campaign, as is the National’s candidate Marty Corboy, with Labor candidate Eric Kerr and the Greens candidate Jenny O’Connor. But the three-cornered contest – McGowan, Mirabella and Corboy – is the one to watch. At the campaign launch, McGowan made much of her voting record in the 44th parliament. She told the audience that out of 547 bills, she voted with the Coalition on 443 occasions, Labor on 32 occasions, and nine times against both major parties. The government passed 475 bills. She rejected the major party view of independents – suggesting the regional seat had a “real presence” in Canberra. “Indi really matters now and is getting more attention than ever,” McGowan said. “Making the seat marginal and competitive has delivered for Indi.” “Fears of the electorate being starved of funding with an independent at the helm proved false. In excess of $800m of taxpayers’ money has been committed to Indi and it continues.” McGowan, who campaigned on mobile black spots in 2013, claimed her collaborative work establishing the Indi Telecommunication Action Group brought about the construction of 30 mobile phone towers under the Coalition. “This result was outstanding,” McGowan said. “But the way we did it – the Indi Way – was even more impressive and showed how the collective momentum of working together is greater than the sum of the parts.” And in a direct rebuff to the National party, she claimed no major party had a vision for regional Australia. “Regional development underpins the majority of my work in parliament – there’s such a gap – with no major party having a strong coherent plan for regional Australia,” McGowan said. “We need a national approach to building our regions - including regional higher education, regional health, regional manufacturing, regional transport – indeed we need a vision for regional Australia.” McGowan outlined her support for marriage equality and flagged that she would vote in favour for any bill to come before the parliament, notwithstanding the Coalition’s intention to hold a plebiscite on the issue. McGowan also pledged to support fixed four year terms, which are a feature of the New South Wales parliament. McGowan said a grassroots community event called the Indi Summit identified three issues that mattered to the electorate, employment opportunities, particularly for young people, renewable energy and the role of the arts. “There was a clear message from the Summit that our planet matters: there is a unique opportunity for Indi to work together to increase our use of renewable energy and thus lessen our carbon foot print,” McGowan said.
